messages: 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (17:55): 7e9ffbe20643381020df06acbfcae9bf, the <nav> element is not a replacement so much as a new, semantics-only element, so there are no rules on what it should be around, or what should be in it. If you add it, clients that understand "intention" expressed with things like <nav> and <section> etc. will be able to understand you better, but that's all they do. So no rules on what should, or should not, be in them in terms
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (17:55): of HTML. Only on what they should contain in terms of "what the data represents"
7e9ffbe20643381020df06acbfcae9bf (17:56): 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b: Yeah but there's always a common consensus on what's considered good practice.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (17:56): true. I think a list apart did a good job establishing that your nav menu as a ul makes more sense than as a collection of anchors =)
c5292ef67d94fef9037d7e67efc58b3d (18:00): I'm having a bizarre issue with iOS viewing an encrypted site, it's throwing an error about the cert
c5292ef67d94fef9037d7e67efc58b3d (18:00): but yet on the desktop, the cert is fine    https://wartburg.webfood.com/m/
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:00): is it using one of the recently recalled certificates?
c5292ef67d94fef9037d7e67efc58b3d (18:00): it's a  *.webfood.com   cert
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:00): The site's security certificate is not trusted!

0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:00): You attempted to reach wartburg.webfood.com, but the server presented a certificate issued by an entity that is not trusted by your computer's operating system. This may mean that the server has generated its own security credentials, which Google Chrome cannot rely on for identity information, or an attacker may be trying to intercept your communications. You should not proceed, especially if
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:00): you have never seen this warning before for this site.
c5292ef67d94fef9037d7e67efc58b3d (18:01): that recalled one, iirc, was updated in my browsers awhile ago, my iOS is only 5.0.0 which is older than my desktop
c5292ef67d94fef9037d7e67efc58b3d (18:01): nope
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:01): Chrome doesn't like this certificate either
c5292ef67d94fef9037d7e67efc58b3d (18:01): really, my chrome isn't complaining at all
c5292ef67d94fef9037d7e67efc58b3d (18:02): nor IE9
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:03): ust-in-digicert-certificates-178092
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:03): http://www.infoworld.com/d/security/mozilla-microsoft-withdraw-trust-in-digicert-certificates-178092
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:03): and this is a 2010 digicert certificate.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:03): I expect they've been blacklisted or flagged by others too
c5292ef67d94fef9037d7e67efc58b3d (18:04): nor FF9
e9c1e4a7d968305603dda4e497fde9fe (18:05): can i use input type file and type radiobutton together in one namespace, so that i have either checked that radiobutton or selected a file to upload?
c5292ef67d94fef9037d7e67efc58b3d (18:05): 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b: ahh thanks!
e9c1e4a7d968305603dda4e497fde9fe (18:05): without using javascript to check it, that is
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:07): e9c1e4a7d968305603dda4e497fde9fe: namespace?
e9c1e4a7d968305603dda4e497fde9fe (18:08): well, having the same name="thisismynamespace" attribute
e9c1e4a7d968305603dda4e497fde9fe (18:08): so that they know they belong together
e9c1e4a7d968305603dda4e497fde9fe (18:08): providing an either-or decision
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:09): wonder what the actual name for that is, since namespace traditionally refers to the markup language element namespace.
e9c1e4a7d968305603dda4e497fde9fe (18:09): i want to have an option to either upload a new image or the option to not change the picture
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:09): hmm, I'm not sure you can do that without some js, but let's finnd out
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:09): *finnd
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:09): I guess that n really wants to be there
e9c1e4a7d968305603dda4e497fde9fe (18:09): to much coffee ;)
e9c1e4a7d968305603dda4e497fde9fe (18:10): i tried setting the same name attribute, but it doesnt recognize that here
e9c1e4a7d968305603dda4e497fde9fe (18:10): i set the radiobutton to checked in the first place
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:10): I'm almost sure that you can't do that across different types, but I'm looking it up
e9c1e4a7d968305603dda4e497fde9fe (18:11): but when i add a file to the file input, the checking of the radio button still stays

0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:15): I radio button group behaviour does not apply to anything that's not a radio button, so if you have an input type="file" name="thesameastheradiobutton", the radiobutton state will have no effect on the file input element.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:15): http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html#radio-button-state-type-radio
c5292ef67d94fef9037d7e67efc58b3d (18:17): 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b: further investigation is that there are two companies called DigiCert
c5292ef67d94fef9037d7e67efc58b3d (18:18): 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b: I'm not sure if the cert for our other domain is the same DigiCert or not, but it's still legit
c5292ef67d94fef9037d7e67efc58b3d (18:18): kind of funny since the one is question is 256bit and the one that's ok is 128bit
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (18:22): weird

34b0d246331696992e9ee7235f88ca66 (18:23): and failing that, is there anything in the newer browsers that lets me access the clipboard
